NEWS-LETTER
STAGES
DEBATE ON LEAGUE.
George R. Gaither, Republican, and
Isadore Goldstrom, Democrat,
Discuss Question at Fifth Assembly—Presidential
Straw Vote
Taken.

The regular weekly assembly
last Thursday was devoted to a
discussion on the League of
Nations. Mr. George R. Gaither
presented the Republican side of
the question and Mr. Isadore
Goldstrom represented the Democratic viewpoint. The discussion
was arranged for and the speakers obtained by the NEWS-LETTER.
Although the meeting was ostensibly intended as a debate on the
League of Nations, neither speaker confined himself wholly to that
topic, but• paid some attention to
nearly all the points of difference
between the two parties.
Mr. Gaither, who spoke first, defined what he considered the four
chief issues of the campaign: A
return to constitutional government and an abandonment of the
present "one-man" rule, a vigorous
Americanism which places the in.
terests of this country above those
of the world at large, the placing
in power of a party with a constructive policy and the League of
Nations. He then proceeded to attack the conditions under which
the treaty was written and the
"unparalleled orgy of grabbing"
which took place at Versailles, in
which every nation but the United
States had a part. Mr. Gaither
further pointed out that entering
the League would mean that we
guaranteed, under Article X the
European nations in the possession of the territory thus acquired
and an abandonment of our traditional policy of isolation.
In replying to his opponent Mr.
Goldstrom touched on a great variety of topics. He called attention to the inefficiency of past
Republican administrations, and
characterized their opposition to
the treaty and to the League as insincere and partisan. Further he
criticised the Republicans for centering their attention on the material prosperity of America alone,
and ignoring the higher interests
of the world at large. The League
he considers the best method so
far advanced for preventing future
wars, chiefly through the very
fact.of its existence and the potential might it would represent.

HAMPDEN
TO
WALTER
SPEAK AT NEXT
ASSEMBLY.
Playlets Fast Rounding into Form—
Paintings By Carol Sax on Exhibition at Barn.

The appearance of Walter
distinguished
Hampden, t h e
Shakespearian actor, at next
Thursday's Assembly is being
eagerly awaited by those who
know of his unusual work. The
arrangements for his attendance
have been completed by Bartus
Trew, president of the Dramatic
Club, who has had charge of the
disposal of tickets for Mr. Hampden's performances of last night
and tonight. Tickets for tonight's
performance may still be procured
from Holmes Bryd at a reduction
of 50 cents.
The plays now under rehearsal
are fast rounding into shape suitable for the production they will
receive late in November. "Joe"
Moran, besides being author and
coach of the one play, will probably star in the other by Emory
Basford.
For four days, beginning Election Day, November 2, the Dramatic Club will have on view in
its studio at the top of the "Barn"
an exhibition of paintings, Cubist,
Futuristic, Meo and Post Cubic, by
Carol Sax and one of his pupils,
which for the last few weeks has .
been open to inspection at the Belvedere. This is a rare opportunity
for every student to acquaint himself with the unusual things now
being done by Baltimore artists in
these hitherto unexplored fields.

Debs. Christiansen. Watkins.

BLACK
AND
BLUEJAY
WELL UNDER WAY.
Interesting Number Promised for
Thanksgiving—More Copy
Needed—Many Vacancies on Staff.

Plans for the publication of the
initial Thanksgiving number of
"The Black and Bluejay" are
rapidly materializing. A considerable amount of "copy" has been
handed to the editorial board, including several short stories, plays
and poems of a humorous nature.
The business staff has been very
successful in securing a number of
advertisements. The new magazine has received the endorsement
of the Merchants and Manufacturers Associations of this city, which
practically assures its success
financially. The business men of
Baltimore have long realized the
desirability of having such a publication as the new magazine at
the University, as they believe it
will come into the hands of a large
number of people who would not
be interested in the NEWS-LETTER.
The enterprise is viewed with
favor by a number of people other
than business men, who, although
not associated with Johns Hopkins, are interested in its progress.
It can readily be said that with
the support and co-operation of
the student-body the Black and
Bluejay is certain of success. An
interesting and entertaining number is expected in the Thanksgiving issue, which will be distributed
on November 23rd.
The advent of the new magazine
will mark .another step in the

VARSITY SCORES AGAINST BLUE
AND GRAY.
Georgetown Machine Rolls Up With
Difficulty 28 Points Against the
Black and Blue—Calkins and
Wood Stars for Hopkins.

In losing to Georgetown University last Saturday, 28 to 7, the
Johns Hopkins football team made
one of the greatest fights ever seen
on Homewood Field. Heavily outweighed and supposedly outclassed, they battled the Washingtonians, a team that ranks among
the strongest in the East, every
minute of the game, and forced
them to display everything they
had in stock to put over their four
touchdowns. With the exception
of the second quarter, when,
Georgetown scored 21 points, it
was anybody's game, for, despite
the magnificent end runs of Flavin
and Malley, the Hopkins line held
at the right moments, so that the
first period went scoreless and the
second half gave a touchdown to
each team.
To Bill Wood belongs the glory
for doing the thing that Hopkins'
most ardent supporters did not
dare to hope for—scoring a touchdown against the Blue and Gray.
Always the first man down the
field under a punt, he was ready
and waiting when Malley signalled
for a fair catch and then dropped
the ball. With a rush he had
snatched up the bounding pikskin
and was away on a straight dash
of 40 yards for the goal line, across
which he dived with a Georgetown
man only a step behind him. Marken kicked goal amid the frenzied
cheers of the tumultuous Hopkins stands.
From the Georgetown standpoint, the outstanding figures were
Malley and Flavin. Aided by almost perfect interference, they
time and again dashed around the
Hopkins ends for gains of 20 or
30 yards. On the other side of
the line Eric Calkins was in the
spotlight with his splendid kicking, his 30-yard run through the
line and his long forward pass,
caught by Middleton. To Dodson
and Gregg much praise is also due
for the highly creditable manner
in which they handled the team.
During the first quarter neither
squad showed anything remarkable in the way of an offensive, although Georgetown made several
large gains, the effect of which was
lost in the remarkable string of
penalties. Early in the second
period, however, slashing end runs
by the Blue and Gray backs soon

PROF. LOVEJOY TO ADDRESS SOCIAL SCIENCE
CLUB.
Interesting Schedule Arranged By Club
for First Semester—Public Invited to Attend all
Addresses.

The first public lecture of the
Social Science Club will be held
on Thursday, November 4, when
Prof. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, of this
University, will speak on "ProfitSharing and Industrial Peace."
Dr. Lovejoy is head of the Department of Philosophy and a recognized authority in the field of political philosophy and sociology.
The lecture is open to the public
and a large attendance is expected.
This will be only the first of a
series of interesting addresses to
be delivered this year under the
auspices of the Social Science
Club. In November Dr. David A.
McCabe, professor of political
economy at Princeton, will speak
on "The Problem of Industrial
Peace." Dr. McCabe is a noted
economist and his lecture will
doubtlessly be highly interesting.
Following this lecture Father
Ryan, of Catholic University, will
speak on "A Pair Wage," on December 10. In January Dr. H. W.
L.aidler, of the
Intercollegiate Socialist Society, will deliver an address on some phase of socialism.
Dr. Laidler has
written several
books on socialism, and is very

MONUMENTAL
CLUB
ORGANIZED.

ORATORICAL CLUB PLANS TO
HOLD MOCK TRIAL

To most of the student-body today the term "brick-age" implies
something old—at least too old to
be a part of the present-day college. When anyone says that he
was a member of the University
in the "brick-age" days he is immediately thought of as an alumnus with gray hair or with a wife
and family. When the University
moved to Homewood in 1916 this
age ceased and a new era began.
And yet there are still Undergraduates today who took undergraduate courses in the old Monument Street buildings, and hence
belong to the "brick-age" and who
are still pursuing courses for a
B. A. or a B. S. degree today.
These men have formed a club
called the Monumental Club. It
is so small this year that its presence cannot be felt as it should be,
but it still stays together to remind and perpetuate the older
Hopkins ideas. Anyone who has
failed to enroll and who is interested in the Monumental Club
should see Harold Reed, '21.

The Oratorical Club plans to
add mock trials and debates to its
present program of extemporaneous and impromptu speaking. The
mock trials, besides affording an
amusing diversion, will give valuable practice and experience to
those who desire to enter the profession of law. The debates will
be held by the Oratorical Club
with similar clubs of other universities in the near vicinity. Nothing definite has been done in regards to the arrangement of debates, as the approval of the Debating Council, which has not held
a meeting so far this year, is necessary. It is, however, believed by
some that a debate could be arranged with Loyola College.
An interesting meeting is expected next Friday, when Mr.
George Goetz will deliver an address on "Mr. Debs, the Man," and
Mr. Debs' political tenets will be
discussed, Mr. Bernard Ades espousing them and Mr. Henry West
in opposition. A peppy meeting
is promised and all students interested in public speaking are invited to attend. The meeting will
be held at the Johns Hopkins Club
Friday, at 8 P. M.

well informed on modern socialistic tendencies.
This program
merely covers the first semester,
which will be followed by a series
of equally interesting lectures the
second half year.

Hopkins Will Not Send Expedition to
South America.

Johns Hopkins will not co-operate with Columbia and Harvard
Universities in sending an expedition to South America to study
the region near the Amazon River
basin, according to Dr. Berry of
the Department of Palentology.
Dr. Berry said that the Associated Press reports to the above
effect in the local dailies were incorrect, and that Hopkins had no
intention or desire to send out any
more expeditions to Brazil. "The
Singewald expedition last year is
the last research party that Hopkins will send out for some time,"
said Dr. Berry.

Baseball Team Elects Sharretts Captain. Not Yet Ratified by
A. A. Board.

At a recent meeting of the members of -the 1920 Baseball Team C.
Roland Sharretts, Jr.,'22, was for
the second time unanimously
elected captain of this year's team.
For some obscure reason the Athletic Board decided last spring
that the election should be postponed until this year. Since the
team has unanimously reaffirmed
its first choice it is expected that
the Board will ratify Sharrett's
election.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 2, 1920

Those of us who went to Homewood last Saturday expecting to
see Hopkins snowed under, and
fearing that the onslaughts and
notoriously rough play of the
Georgetown eleven would injure
for the• remainder of the season
some of the Varsity's best players,
were very agreeably surprised.
Not only was no one hurt seriously—several were taken out due
to minor injuries, but none will
be forced to remain out of the
game any length of time—but also
the team put up a corking good
game, fighting every inch of the
way against heavy odds.
The end-run plays were the only
steady gainers for the visitors, as
the line held time after time when
Malley or Flavin hit center or
guard, often throwing them for
losses. If the line works like this
for the remainder of the season,
Hopkins' opponents will have to
resort to other tactics to advance
the ball. Nice headwork on the
part of the backfield, and especially of Markell and Dodson,
foiled repeated, attempts to gain
by aerial attacks.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 2 1920

LITERARY CLUB MEETS.
The Literary Club met Friday
evening at 8 P. M. at the Johns
Hopkins Club. The meeting was
poorly attended, due no doubt to
the inclemency of the weather. The
main event was a talk by Adolphus
Emmart on Samuel Butler. Emmart treated him not as a scientist
but as a man and an author. He
spoke of his bitterness and extreme cynicism and his lack of
faith in life. The speaker also referred to three of Butler's works:
"Erhewhoii," "Way of All Flesh"
and his notebooks. The talk was
most scholarly, as are all the talks
Mr. Emmart gives, and it is to be
regretted that more were not there
to hear him.

Frederick Jones Bliss, Ph. D., of
New Haven, Conn. author of "The
Religions of Modern Syria and
Palestine," "Tell el-Hesy, a Mound
of Many Cities," etc., will give six
public lectures on the following
topics:
Friday, November 12—Islam in
Syria.

Wednesday, November 17—The
Druses and the Lebanon.
Friday, November 19—Theology

Wednesday, November 24—Modernism among the Druses.

and Thirty-second Streets. Cards
of admission will not be requisite.

Unwarranted Gaiety.

It was in January, 1919, when
everybody in France was getting
disgusted with all wars in general
and their private one in particular. A colored soldier, engaged in
the unheroic task of policing the
road, was leaning on his implement of war—a shovel—reflecting
on all the disadvantages of being
alive, when a happy doughboy
wearing three service chevrons
passed, singing at the top of his
lungs.
The darky gazed incredulously
at the soldier and his service chevrons and then returned his attention to the landscape.
"Mah Lawd !" he muttered, "'at
man done been over.heah eighteen
months and he still know some
tune besides 'Hark, from de
Tomb.'"—American Legion Weekly.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 2, 1920
R. 0. T. C. TO GIVE DRESS
PARADE.
Band From Camp Holabird to Furnish
Music—President Goodnow to
Review Unit—Major Gary
Applauds Work of
Students.

On Tuesday, November 9, the
R. 0. T. C. Unit will hold a formal
full-dress parade, with the band
from Camp Holabird to furnish
the music. The entire unite will
participate. After the parade
there will be a review for the
President of the University on the
upper quadrangle in front of Gilman Hall.
This will be the second of a
series of exhibition drills that the
Johns Hopkins Unit is giving from
time to time. It is by the courtesy and generosity of Lieut-Col.
George B. Sharon, commander of
Camp Holabird, that the Holabird
Band will be present to render the
ceremony so much niore impressive.
Beginning the first of this
month the different classes in the
battalion are being started on
their major studies of the year.
The First Year Basic Course men
(Freshmen) will continue in infantry drill work.
The Second
Year Basic (Sophomores) are beginning military map reading and
sketching. The First Year Advanced (Sophomores) are beginning military field engineering.
The Second Year Basic have taken
up musketry.
The following statement, quoting Major Gary, and agreed to by
his assistants, Captain McMurray
and Sergeant Grummen, indicates
that the unit is in a fair way to
capture a "distinguished service"
rating. Major Gary said: "I am
very much pleased with the way
the men in the R. O. T. C. Unit
in general are starting their year's
work. If the effort thus started
will be continued there is no questioning, in my judgment, the position the unit will occupy at the
end of the year."

THE NEWS LETTER'S
MAILBAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be printed
if request is made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by
THE NEWS-LETTER, Which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
Interest.

To the Editor of the Mail Bag:
Dear Sir—In the editorial section of the News-Letter of October
19 there was an article deploring
the poor rooting that is going on
this year.
It is true that the
cheering is the poorest that I have
ever known it to be in the five
years that I have been connected
with the University. According
to the article much of this poor
rooting is "caused by the Freshmen who do not know the yells."
It is perhaps true that the Freshmen are not up to the standard in
this respect, but I want to say
that the real cause of the trouble
is not with the Freshmen or any
of the rooters in general, but with
the yell leaders themselves. How
in the Sam Hill can anybody expect any decent yelling when the
leaders are never in time with
each other and one is always a
half an hour behind the other.
Not only are they out of time with
each other but the motions of the
two vary so much with respect to
each other that it would make a
monkey cross-eyed if he tried to
follow them both. In other words
there is an entire lack of co-ordination on their part. Until this
is remedied you can abuse the
poor Freshmen without ceasing
and hold yell practices until
doomsday, but the yelling will not
improve.
In all colleges where the yelling is most effective the yell leaders are trained to act like one machine. They all make the same
motions at the same time. The
very sight of this harmony of motion and rythm acts in such a way
as to inspire the rooters to their
best endeavor, and cannot fail to
bring good results. I do not wish
to be too hard on the yell leaders
because I know they are working
hard and trying their best to make
the cheers as good as possible.
They are going about it in the
wrong way, however, and will
never get good results until they
themselves are in perfect co-ordination. I suggest therefore that
they have practice among themselves and adopt the method of
simultaneous motion which has
worked so well in other colleges.
It is only in this manner that
Hopkins will be unashamed of its
yelling.
ED HOFFMEISTER.

NEWS-LETTER STAGES DEBATE

STARTS
ORCHESTRA
REHEARSALS.
Third Season in Full Swing—Under
Leadership of Mr. Charles H.
Bochau—Needs Support of
Student-Body.

The Johns Hopkins University
Orchestra, now in its third season,
has started its regular weekly rehearsals on Tuesday evenings at
the Peabody Institute.
The officers of the orchestra are
striving to show the benefits of
training in music which will lead
to the introduction of a Department of Music as a part of the
University. By admitting outside
musicians there is now a complete
and permanent symphony orchestra with all instruments represented; whereas, with the constantly changing student body and
limited number of orchestral players to be found, it would not be
possible to form a symphony orchestra exclusively of students
which would be in any way permanent,
Last season the orchestra made
several public appearances, playing at the University Commencement Exercises in February and
June, besides giving concerts at
the Peabody Institute, Johns Hopkins Hospital, Maryland Institute
for the Blind, the Church Home
and Infirmary, the Woman's Hospital and St. Agnes' Hospital.
Though this year's schedule is not
definitely known, it is thought certain that there will be two or more
out-of-town concerts in addition to
these.

VOL. XXV. No. 5
NEWS-LETTER
STAGES
DEBATE ON LEAGUE.
George R. Gaither, Republican, and
Isadore Goldstrom, Democrat,
Discuss Question at Fifth Assembly—Presidential
Straw Vote
Taken.

The regular weekly assembly
last Thursday was devoted to a
discussion on the League of
Nations. Mr. George R. Gaither
presented the Republican side of
the question and Mr. Isadore
Goldstrom represented the Democratic viewpoint. The discussion
was arranged for and the speakers obtained by the NEWS-LETTER.
Although the meeting was ostensibly intended as a debate on the
League of Nations, neither speaker confined himself wholly to that
topic, but• paid some attention to
nearly all the points of difference
between the two parties.
Mr. Gaither, who spoke first, defined what he considered the four
chief issues of the campaign: A
return to constitutional government and an abandonment of the
present "one-man" rule, a vigorous
Americanism which places the in.
terests of this country above those
of the world at large, the placing
in power of a party with a constructive policy and the League of
Nations. He then proceeded to attack the conditions under which
the treaty was written and the
"unparalleled orgy of grabbing"
which took place at Versailles, in
which every nation but the United
States had a part. Mr. Gaither
further pointed out that entering
the League would mean that we
guaranteed, under Article X the
European nations in the possession of the territory thus acquired
and an abandonment of our traditional policy of isolation.
In replying to his opponent Mr.
Goldstrom touched on a great variety of topics. He called attention to the inefficiency of past
Republican administrations, and
characterized their opposition to
the treaty and to the League as insincere and partisan. Further he
criticised the Republicans for centering their attention on the material prosperity of America alone,
and ignoring the higher interests
of the world at large. The League
he considers the best method so
far advanced for preventing future
wars, chiefly through the very
fact.of its existence and the potential might it would represent.

TO

SPEAK AT NEXT
ASSEMBLY.
Playlets Fast Rounding into Form—
Paintings By Carol Sax on Exhibition at Barn.

The appearance of Walter
distinguished
Hampden, t h e
Shakespearian actor, at next
Thursday's Assembly is being
eagerly awaited by those who
know of his unusual work. The
arrangements for his attendance
have been completed by Bartus
Trew, president of the Dramatic
Club, who has had charge of the
disposal of tickets for Mr. Hampden's performances of last night
and tonight. Tickets for tonight's
performance may still be procured
from Holmes Bryd at a reduction
of 50 cents.
The plays now under rehearsal
are fast rounding into shape suitable for the production they will
receive late in November. "Joe"
Moran, besides being author and
coach of the one play, will probably star in the other by Emory
Basford.
For four days, beginning Election Day, November 2, the Dramatic Club will have on view in
its studio at the top of the "Barn"
an exhibition of paintings, Cubist,
Futuristic, Meo and Post Cubic, by
Carol Sax and one of his pupils,
which for the last few weeks has .
been open to inspection at the Belvedere. This is a rare opportunity
for every student to acquaint himself with the unusual things now
being done by Baltimore artists in
these hitherto unexplored fields.

Debs. Christiansen. Watkins.

AND
BLUEJAY
WELL UNDER WAY.
Interesting Number Promised for
Thanksgiving—More Copy
Needed—Many Vacancies on Staff.

Plans for the publication of the
initial Thanksgiving number of
"The Black and Bluejay" are
rapidly materializing. A considerable amount of "copy" has been
handed to the editorial board, including several short stories, plays
and poems of a humorous nature.
The business staff has been very
successful in securing a number of
advertisements. The new magazine has received the endorsement
of the Merchants and Manufacturers Associations of this city, which
practically assures its success
financially. The business men of
Baltimore have long realized the
desirability of having such a publication as the new magazine at
the University, as they believe it
will come into the hands of a large
number of people who would not
be interested in the NEWS-LETTER.
The enterprise is viewed with
favor by a number of people other
than business men, who, although
not associated with Johns Hopkins, are interested in its progress.
It can readily be said that with
the support and co-operation of
the student-body the Black and
Bluejay is certain of success. An
interesting and entertaining number is expected in the Thanksgiving issue, which will be distributed
on November 23rd.

VARSITY SCORES AGAINST BLUE
AND GRAY.
Georgetown Machine Rolls Up With
Difficulty 28 Points Against the
Black and Blue—Calkins and
Wood Stars for Hopkins.

In losing to Georgetown University last Saturday, 28 to 7, the
Johns Hopkins football team made
one of the greatest fights ever seen
on Homewood Field. Heavily outweighed and supposedly outclassed, they battled the Washingtonians, a team that ranks among
the strongest in the East, every
minute of the game, and forced
them to display everything they
had in stock to put over their four
touchdowns. With the exception
of the second quarter, when,
Georgetown scored 21 points, it
was anybody's game, for, despite
the magnificent end runs of Flavin
and Malley, the Hopkins line held
at the right moments, so that the
first period went scoreless and the
second half gave a touchdown to
each team.
To Bill Wood belongs the glory
for doing the thing that Hopkins'
most ardent supporters did not
dare to hope for—scoring a touchdown against the Blue and Gray.
Always the first man down the
field under a punt, he was ready
and waiting when Malley signalled
for a fair catch and then dropped
the ball. With a rush he had
snatched up the bounding pikskin
and was away on a straight dash
of 40 yards for the goal line, across
which he dived with a Georgetown
man only a step behind him. Marken kicked goal amid the frenzied
cheers of the tumultuous Hopkins stands.
From the Georgetown standpoint, the outstanding figures were
Malley and Flavin. Aided by almost perfect interference, they
time and again dashed around the
Hopkins ends for gains of 20 or
30 yards. On the other side of
the line Eric Calkins was in the
spotlight with his splendid kicking, his 30-yard run through the
line and his long forward pass,
caught by Middleton. To Dodson
and Gregg much praise is also due
for the highly creditable manner
in which they handled the team.
During the first quarter neither
squad showed anything remarkable in the way of an offensive, although Georgetown made several
large gains, the effect of which was
lost in the remarkable string of
penalties. Early in the second
period, however, slashing end runs
by the Blue and Gray backs soon

PROF. LOVEJOY TO ADDRESS SOCIAL SCIENCE
CLUB.
Interesting Schedule Arranged By Club
for First Semester—Public Invited to Attend all
Addresses.

The first public lecture of the
Social Science Club will be held
on Thursday, November 4, when
Prof. Arthur 0. Lovejoy, of this
University, will speak on "ProfitSharing and Industrial Peace."
Dr. Lovejoy is head of the Department of Philosophy and a recognized authority in the field of political philosophy and sociology.
The lecture is open to the public
and a large attendance is expected.
This will be only the first of a
series of interesting addresses to
be delivered this year under the
auspices of the Social Science
Club. In November Dr. David A.
McCabe, professor of political
economy at Princeton, will speak
on "The Problem of Industrial
Peace." Dr. McCabe is a noted
economist and his lecture will
doubtlessly be highly interesting.
Following this lecture Father
Ryan, of Catholic University, will
speak on "A Pair Wage," on December 10. In January Dr. H. W.
L.aidler, of the
Intercollegiate Socialist Society, will deliver an address on some phase of socialism.
Dr. Laidler has
written several
books on socialism, and is very

MONUMENTAL
CLUB
ORGANIZED.

ORATORICAL CLUB PLANS TO
HOLD MOCK TRIAL

To most of the student-body today the term "brick-age" implies
something old—at least too old to
be a part of the present-day college. When anyone says that he
was a member of the University
in the "brick-age" days he is immediately thought of as an alumnus with gray hair or with a wife
and family. When the University
moved to Homewood in 1916 this
age ceased and a new era began.
And yet there are still Undergraduates today who took undergraduate courses in the old Monument Street buildings, and hence
belong to the "brick-age" and who
are still pursuing courses for a
B. A. or a B. S. degree today.
These men have formed a club
called the Monumental Club. It
is so small this year that its presence cannot be felt as it should be,
but it still stays together to remind and perpetuate the older
Hopkins ideas. Anyone who has
failed to enroll and who is interested in the Monumental Club
should see Harold Reed, '21.

The Oratorical Club plans to
add mock trials and debates to its
present program of extemporaneous and impromptu speaking. The
mock trials, besides affording an
amusing diversion, will give valuable practice and experience to
those who desire to enter the profession of law. The debates will
be held by the Oratorical Club
with similar clubs of other universities in the near vicinity. Nothing definite has been done in regards to the arrangement of debates, as the approval of the Debating Council, which has not held
a meeting so far this year, is necessary. It is, however, believed by
some that a debate could be arranged with Loyola College.
An interesting meeting is expected next Friday, when Mr.
George Goetz will deliver an address on "Mr. Debs, the Man," and
Mr. Debs' political tenets will be
discussed, Mr. Bernard Ades espousing them and Mr. Henry West
in opposition. A peppy meeting
is promised and all students interested in public speaking are invited to attend. The meeting will
be held at the Johns Hopkins Club
Friday, at 8 P. M.

well informed on modern socialistic tendencies.
This program
merely covers the first semester,
which will be followed by a series
of equally interesting lectures the
second half year.

Hopkins Will Not Send Expedition to
South America.

Johns Hopkins will not co-operate with Columbia and Harvard
Universities in sending an expedition to South America to study
the region near the Amazon River
basin, according to Dr. Berry of
the Department of Palentology.
Dr. Berry said that the Associated Press reports to the above
effect in the local dailies were incorrect, and that Hopkins had no
intention or desire to send out any
more expeditions to Brazil. "The
Singewald expedition last year is
the last research party that Hopkins will send out for some time,"
said Dr. Berry.

Baseball Team Elects Sharretts Captain. Not Yet Ratified by
A. A. Board.

At a recent meeting of the members of -the 1920 Baseball Team C.
Roland Sharretts, Jr.,'22, was for
the second time unanimously
elected captain of this year's team.
For some obscure reason the Athletic Board decided last spring
that the election should be postponed until this year. Since the
team has unanimously reaffirmed
its first choice it is expected that
the Board will ratify Sharrett's
election.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 2, 1920

Those of us who went to Homewood last Saturday expecting to
see Hopkins snowed under, and
fearing that the onslaughts and
notoriously rough play of the
Georgetown eleven would injure
for the• remainder of the season
some of the Varsity's best players,
were very agreeably surprised.
Not only was no one hurt seriously—several were taken out due
to minor injuries, but none will
be forced to remain out of the
game any length of time—but also
the team put up a corking good
game, fighting every inch of the
way against heavy odds.
The end-run plays were the only
steady gainers for the visitors, as
the line held time after time when
Malley or Flavin hit center or
guard, often throwing them for
losses. If the line works like this
for the remainder of the season,
Hopkins' opponents will have to
resort to other tactics to advance
the ball. Nice headwork on the
part of the backfield, and especially of Markell and Dodson,
foiled repeated, attempts to gain
by aerial attacks.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 2 1920

LITERARY CLUB MEETS.
The Literary Club met Friday
evening at 8 P. M. at the Johns
Hopkins Club. The meeting was
poorly attended, due no doubt to
the inclemency of the weather. The
main event was a talk by Adolphus
Emmart on Samuel Butler. Emmart treated him not as a scientist
but as a man and an author. He
spoke of his bitterness and extreme cynicism and his lack of
faith in life. The speaker also referred to three of Butler's works:
"Erhewhoii," "Way of All Flesh"
and his notebooks. The talk was
most scholarly, as are all the talks
Mr. Emmart gives, and it is to be
regretted that more were not there
to hear him.

THE SECRET CULTS OF SYRIA
Frederick Jones Bliss, Ph. D., of
New Haven, Conn. author of "The
Religions of Modern Syria and
Palestine," "Tell el-Hesy, a Mound
of Many Cities," etc., will give six
public lectures on the following
topics:
Friday, November 12—Islam in
Syria.
Monday, November 15 — The
Isma'ilian Basis of the Cults.
Wednesday, November 17—The
Druses and the Lebanon.
Friday, November 19—Theology
of the Druses.
Monday, November 22— The
Isma'ilis of Today. The Nusairis.
Wednesday, November 24—Modernism among the Druses.
The lectures will be given at 5
o'clock in the hall of the Civil Engineering Building. They will begin punctually and end within the
hour. The most convenient entrance to the grounds is at Charles

Unwarranted Gaiety.

It was in January, 1919, when
everybody in France was getting
disgusted with all wars in general
and their private one in particular. A colored soldier, engaged in
the unheroic task of policing the
road, was leaning on his implement of war—a shovel—reflecting
on all the disadvantages of being
alive, when a happy doughboy
wearing three service chevrons
passed, singing at the top of his
lungs.
The darky gazed incredulously
at the soldier and his service chevrons and then returned his attention to the landscape.
"Mah Lawd !" he muttered, "'at
man done been over.heah eighteen
months and he still know some
tune besides 'Hark, from de
Tomb.'"—American Legion Weekly.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 2, 1920
R. 0. T. C. TO GIVE DRESS
PARADE.
Band From Camp Holabird to Furnish
Music—President Goodnow to
Review Unit—Major Gary
Applauds Work of
Students.

On Tuesday, November 9, the
R. 0. T. C. Unit will hold a formal
full-dress parade, with the band
from Camp Holabird to furnish
the music. The entire unite will
participate. After the parade
there will be a review for the
President of the University on the
upper quadrangle in front of Gilman Hall.
This will be the second of a
series of exhibition drills that the
Johns Hopkins Unit is giving from
time to time. It is by the courtesy and generosity of Lieut-Col.
George B. Sharon, commander of
Camp Holabird, that the Holabird
Band will be present to render the
ceremony so much niore impressive.
Beginning the first of this
month the different classes in the
battalion are being started on
their major studies of the year.
The First Year Basic Course men
(Freshmen) will continue in infantry drill work.
The Second
Year Basic (Sophomores) are beginning military map reading and
sketching. The First Year Advanced (Sophomores) are beginning military field engineering.
The Second Year Basic have taken
up musketry.
The following statement, quoting Major Gary, and agreed to by
his assistants, Captain McMurray
and Sergeant Grummen, indicates
that the unit is in a fair way to
capture a "distinguished service"
rating. Major Gary said: "I am
very much pleased with the way
the men in the R. O. T. C. Unit
in general are starting their year's
work. If the effort thus started
will be continued there is no questioning, in my judgment, the position the unit will occupy at the
end of the year."

THE NEWS LETTER'S
MAILBAG
A Column in Which the Correspondents
Are Allowed Latitude, But Shoulder the Responsibility.
All letters intended for publication
must be concise.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be printed
if request is made that they be omitted.
The publication of a letter is not to be
taken as an indorsement of its views by
THE NEWS-LETTER, Which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
Interest.

To the Editor of the Mail Bag:
Dear Sir—In the editorial section of the News-Letter of October
19 there was an article deploring
the poor rooting that is going on
this year.
It is true that the
cheering is the poorest that I have
ever known it to be in the five
years that I have been connected
with the University. According
to the article much of this poor
rooting is "caused by the Freshmen who do not know the yells."
It is perhaps true that the Freshmen are not up to the standard in
this respect, but I want to say
that the real cause of the trouble
is not with the Freshmen or any
of the rooters in general, but with
the yell leaders themselves. How
in the Sam Hill can anybody expect any decent yelling when the
leaders are never in time with
each other and one is always a
half an hour behind the other.
Not only are they out of time with
each other but the motions of the
two vary so much with respect to
each other that it would make a
monkey cross-eyed if he tried to
follow them both. In other words
there is an entire lack of co-ordination on their part. Until this
is remedied you can abuse the
poor Freshmen without ceasing
and hold yell practices until
doomsday, but the yelling will not
improve.
In all colleges where the yelling is most effective the yell leaders are trained to act like one machine. They all make the same
motions at the same time. The
very sight of this harmony of motion and rythm acts in such a way
as to inspire the rooters to their
best endeavor, and cannot fail to
bring good results. I do not wish
to be too hard on the yell leaders
because I know they are working
hard and trying their best to make
the cheers as good as possible.
They are going about it in the
wrong way, however, and will
never get good results until they
themselves are in perfect co-ordination. I suggest therefore that
they have practice among themselves and adopt the method of
simultaneous motion which has
worked so well in other colleges.
It is only in this manner that
Hopkins will be unashamed of its
yelling.
ED HOFFMEISTER.

NEWS-LETTER STAGES DEBATE
(Continued from page 1, col. 1)

STARTS
ORCHESTRA
REHEARSALS.
Third Season in Full Swing—Under
Leadership of Mr. Charles H.
Bochau—Needs Support of
Student-Body.

The Johns Hopkins University
Orchestra, now in its third season,
has started its regular weekly rehearsals on Tuesday evenings at
the Peabody Institute.
The officers of the orchestra are
striving to show the benefits of
training in music which will lead
to the introduction of a Department of Music as a part of the
University. By admitting outside
musicians there is now a complete
and permanent symphony orchestra with all instruments represented; whereas, with the constantly changing student body and
limited number of orchestral players to be found, it would not be
possible to form a symphony orchestra exclusively of students
which would be in any way permanent,
Last season the orchestra made
several public appearances, playing at the University Commencement Exercises in February and
June, besides giving concerts at
the Peabody Institute, Johns Hopkins Hospital, Maryland Institute
for the Blind, the Church Home
and Infirmary, the Woman's Hospital and St. Agnes' Hospital.
Though this year's schedule is not
definitely known, it is thought certain that there will be two or more
out-of-town concerts in addition to
these.

'Twas a dark and stormy night
and the little squad in the front
trench was darker yet. After a
time a creeping barrage began to
fall and the dusky Yanks listened
to it with increasing anxiety.
"Ah don' like dese heah creepin'
barrages," muttered one fretfully.
"Dey's no wuss dan any
odders," consoled a comrade.
"Dey's mo' nervous-like. Dese
creepin' barrages, dey creeps till
dey gets right on top o' you, and
den dey jes' nacherally pounces
all over you."—American Legion
Weekly.
